title: Project Life Cycles
description: Understand how projects move through predictable phases from initiation to closure.
objectives: Understand the three main project life cycles: Predictive, Adaptive (Agile), and Hybrid
Recognize the characteristics of each life cycle approach
Identify when to use predictive vs adaptive vs hybrid based on project characteristics
Understand the relationship between requirements certainty and approach selection

screens.headline: Carlos's Question: Agile, Waterfall, or Hybrid?

dialogue.text: Alex, we have three projects starting next month. I've heard we should use 'Agile' for everything because it's modern. But our contractor says construction MUST follow a sequential plan. What's the right approach for each project?

screens.learningHook: Not all projects are the same. PREDICTIVE works when requirements are clear. ADAPTIVE works when requirements are uncertain. HYBRID blends both. The right choice depends on project characteristics.

screens.title: Life Cycle Selection
screens.instructions: Match each project to the best life cycle approach based on its characteristics.

projects.title: Project A: New Restaurant Construction
characteristics: Fixed requirements (building codes, permits, floor plan approved)
Sequential phases (permits → foundation → framing → electrical → finishes)
High cost of change (moving walls after framing is expensive)
Stakeholders approve plans upfront, inspect at milestones

projects.title: Project B: Menu Innovation Lab
characteristics: Unclear requirements (need to experiment, get customer feedback)
Iterative development (create → taste test → refine → repeat)
Low cost of change (adjusting ingredients is easy)

projects.title: Project C: Catering Expansion
characteristics: Partially defined requirements (business model clear, operations unclear)
Upfront planning needed (business case, budget, contracts)
Operational flexibility needed (refine based on early feedback)
Stakeholders approve business case upfront, iterate on execution

approaches.name: Predictive (Waterfall)
approaches.whenToUse: Requirements clear, deliverable well-understood, change is costly

approaches.name: Adaptive (Agile)
approaches.whenToUse: Requirements uncertain, innovation needed, customer feedback critical

approaches.name: Hybrid
approaches.whenToUse: Some requirements clear, others uncertain; defined outcomes but flexible paths

questions.question: Match each project to the best life cycle approach:
Why is Predictive (Waterfall) best for the construction project?

options.text: Because it's the most popular approach
Because requirements are fixed and changes after framing are very costly

questions.question: Why is Adaptive (Agile) best for the Menu Innovation Lab?

options.text: Because requirements are uncertain and recipes evolve through experimentation and feedback
Because Maya prefers working in sprints

questions.question: What makes the Catering Expansion a good fit for Hybrid?

options.text: The business plan is fixed (predictive) but operational details need iteration (adaptive)
Carlos can't decide between Agile and Waterfall
Hybrid is always the safest choice

content.concept: Project life cycles exist on a continuum from fully predictive to fully adaptive.
content.insight: Most real-world projects fall somewhere between pure predictive and pure adaptive.

content.definition: A sequential approach where each phase must be completed before the next begins.
risks: Expensive to change late in project

content.definition: An iterative approach where work is done in short cycles with continuous feedback and adaptation.
Combines predictive and adaptive elements based on project needs.

approaches.name: Waterfall for Hardware + Agile for Software
Phase-Gate with Iterations
approaches.example: Formal gates with agile work within phases

blocks.title: How to Choose the Right Approach

decisionFactors.predictive: Limited - approve upfront, review at milestones

content.insight: There's no 'best' approach—only the best approach FOR YOUR PROJECT. Match the approach to project characteristics.

correct.text: Perfect! You matched each project to the right approach. Construction needs predictive, Menu Lab needs adaptive, Catering benefits from hybrid.
Now I understand why we can't use Agile for everything. The contractor was right—construction needs a sequential plan. But our Menu Lab thrives on experimentation.

screens.title: New Project: Mobile Ordering App
screens.context: Savory & Co. wants to build a mobile ordering app. Requirements are unclear (what features do customers want?), technology is evolving, and customer feedback is critical.

questions.question: Which life cycle approach is best for the mobile app project?
Why is Hybrid the right choice for franchise expansion?
questions.instruction: Swipe RIGHT for factors that support Hybrid, LEFT for factors that don't apply.

cards.statement: Business model is CLEAR (fees, royalties, brand standards)
cards.explanation: Clear elements benefit from predictive planning
If equal certainty, wouldn't need hybrid

cards.statement: Carlos needs a fixed business case to approve
cards.explanation: Predictive for governance, adaptive for execution

cards.statement: Franchisee feedback will refine operational details
cards.explanation: Adaptive iteration based on real experience

feedback.high: Excellent! You understand that Hybrid works when SOME elements are clear (plan predictively) and SOME are uncertain (iterate adaptively).
feedback.low: Remember: Hybrid isn't compromise—it's strategic. Use predictive WHERE requirements are clear, adaptive WHERE they're uncertain.

screens.title: Key Takeaways
screens.summary: You've learned the three main project life cycles and when to use each one based on project characteristics.
takeaways: PREDICTIVE (Waterfall): Sequential phases, upfront planning, low change tolerance. Best for clear requirements.
ADAPTIVE (Agile): Iterative cycles, continuous planning, high change tolerance. Best for uncertain requirements.
HYBRID: Blends both approaches. Best when some elements are fixed, others uncertain.
Choose based on: requirements certainty, change tolerance, stakeholder availability, delivery preference
There's no 'best' approach—only the best approach FOR YOUR PROJECT

characterClosing.text: I wanted 'one approach for consistency.' Now I see: using the wrong approach causes more problems than inconsistency. Match the approach to the project!
